;;;;中国;捕鱼船队因非法、未报告和不受监管而名声最差（ ;IUU;）在全球范围内捕鱼。它在南美洲是臭名昭著的。其 3,000 艘船舶中近三分之一全年在该地区运营。为了追逐迁徙的鱿鱼，它们在前六个月在阿根廷附近的大西洋水域掠夺，接下来的六个月则绕过智利的麦哲伦海峡，在厄瓜多尔和秘鲁附近的太平洋海域捕捞捕获的鱿鱼。该舰队目前位于厄瓜多尔海岸附近。但一些国家正在反击。 9月30日，厄瓜多尔、秘鲁、美国和其他11个国家结束了最新的打击;IUU;捕鱼演习，演练拦截船只。

;
;;
;

;在过去的十年里，;IUU;捕鱼已经耗尽全球股票。它每年产生高达 360 亿美元的收入，占全球食用鱼类的五分之一。这使其成为世界第六大非法行业（假冒行业最大，达 1.1 万亿美元，而非法药品位居第二，达 6500 亿美元）。根据华盛顿美国大学的研究，在南美洲，;IUU; 捕鱼导致各国年渔获量减少 8-15%。中国占这些水域外国船只的四分之三。

;

;太平洋的反击从厄瓜多尔附近开始。 2020 年，监视飞行发现 340 艘中国拖网渔船和卷扬船在加拉帕戈斯群岛（海洋保护区）以南拖捞了无数脆弱物种。时任总统莱宁·莫雷诺发誓要保卫这些岛屿。厄瓜多尔的第一步就是要求中国停止非法入侵。秘鲁很快也效仿了。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;在过去三年中，大多数中国船只停留的距离约为 100 公里（60 英里） ）来自两国水域。厄瓜多尔和秘鲁还建立了一个联盟来解决区域性<小>;IUU;捕鱼问题，招募了智利、哥伦比亚、巴拿马和哥斯达黎加。这些国家在2020年公开谴责中国的入侵。次年他们承诺将各自的海洋保护区连接起来，形成世界上最大的保护区，面积是英国的两倍。他们的政府游说世界贸易组织达成一项削减渔业补贴的协议，该协议于 2022 年获得通过。

;

;唐纳德·特朗普和乔·拜登总统都支持南美洲的反击，向太平洋地区提供大量设备和高额渔业资源。 - 技术传感器。 2020 年，<小>;美国;海岸警卫队开始与厄瓜多尔海军一起巡逻。自 2022 年以来，<小>;美国;国务院已筹集近 3000 万美元用于反<小>;IUU;捕鱼计划。

;

;相比之下，阿根廷和乌拉圭的情况是惨淡。 “大西洋的情况变得更糟，”海洋保护主义者米尔科·施瓦茨曼 (Milko Schvartzman) 说。大西洋上的中国船只数量从 2013 年的 74 艘增加到 2021 年的 429 艘。阿根廷左翼总统阿尔贝托·费尔南德斯 (Alberto Fernández) 拒绝敦促加强监管。中国是一个意识形态盟友，也是继巴西之后该国的最大贸易伙伴。与此同时，乌拉圭右翼政府希望中国签署自由贸易协定。每个人都有更大的鱼要煎。 ;■;

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 16:27:03 +0800 What America should really learn from Dianne Feinstein | United Stateshttps://www.economist.com/united-states/2023/10/05/what-america-should-really-learn-from-dianne-feinstein ;
;< /div>;

;;我;;看起来; ;像;另一个时代——几乎是一个时代不同的美国，笼罩在不同的乌云之中——但那只是九年前的一个星期五：时任参议院情报委员会主席的黛安·范斯坦接到了国务卿、老朋友约翰·克里的电话。来自加利福尼亚州的民主党人范斯坦女士刚刚向印刷商发送了她的委员会关于<小>;中央情报局;在 2001 年 9 月 11 日袭击事件后使用酷刑的报告的执行摘要。调查结果将于下周公布，尽管不仅来自中央情报局，而且来自巴拉克·奥巴马(Barack Obama)领导的白宫的强烈抵制，白宫要求进行大量修改，她担心这份报告可能会被“毁掉”。

;
;;
;

;现在克里先生又做出了一项努力，警告她不要泄露这份报告可能会在世界各地引发暴力。他的警告周末得到了美国情报机构的响应，该机构发布了一份威胁评估报告，称该委员会的披露不仅会导致暴力，还会严重损害美国与其他国家的关系。

;

;想象一下责任的分量。范斯坦女士于 9 月 29 日在任内去世，享年 90 岁，她并不是安全国家的敌人。她为政府通过无人机及其监视计划进行的“定点清除”辩护；她将揭露国家安全局清理了美国人电话记录的爱德华·斯诺登视为叛徒。现在，她信任的人和机构预测，如果她继续这样做，她的手上将会沾满鲜血，而且他们可以说她已经被警告过。 “对民选官员的要求太高了，”委员会首席调查员丹尼尔·琼斯 (Daniel Jones) 说。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;范斯坦女士动摇了。她周末咨询了委员会的其他成员以及参议院多数党领袖哈里·里德。有些人提醒她调查结果表明：<小>;中央情报局;连续两次误导白宫和国会以保护其所谓的利益。 <小>;中央情报局;甚至洗劫了该委员会的电脑，并诬告其工作人员违法。其他人则认为，国会不能在如此重要的问题上简单地服从白宫。但截至第二天早上，就连委员会工作人员也不知道范斯坦女士会做什么。然后她离开办公室前往参议院。

;

;当范斯坦女士走上讲台时，她看起来很疲惫，但她的讲话一如既往地坚定而准确。她说，无论该报告可能如何被操纵以证明甚至挑起暴力，“历史将根据我们对公正法治社会的承诺以及面对丑陋事实并说‘再也不会’的意愿来评判我们。”< /p>;

;在一个小时的时间里，她向同事们介绍了这份 500 页的执行摘要中的主要发现，该摘要取自 6,700 页的报告，该报告仍处于机密状态。她回忆起中情局如何在 2006 年（即开始使用“强化审讯技术”四年后）才向她的委员会披露其使用情况。范斯坦女士指出，当时的<小>;中央情报局;主任迈克尔·海登当时作证说，这些技术包括“拍肚子”等创新技术，“危害最小”，并且“应用于高度临床和专业的治疗”。 ”。

;

;“他们不是，”她冰冷克制地继续说道。正如该报告不可磨灭地记录的那样，被拘留者被脱光衣服，穿上尿布，遭受殴打，并被锁成“压力姿势”，双手举过头顶，连续几天不睡觉，被隔离并被泼冷水，并受到武器或伤害的威胁。给他们的家人。有些人被水刑数十次或遭受强制“直肠水化”，以便绑架者能够建立他们所谓的“对被拘留者的完全控制”。琼斯先生和其他工作人员检查了 20 个案例，<小>;中央情报局;声称这些技术产生了关键信息。 “没有一个案例是成立的，”她说。俘虏告诉迫害者他们想听的话。一些;中央情报局;官员反对这些技术，但遭到忽视。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;科罗拉多州前参议员、情报委员会成员马克·乌德尔 (Mark Udall) 表示，范斯坦女士在得知;中央情报局;如何误导国会后感到“痛苦”。 “黛安可能要谨慎一些，”他说。 “在某些方面，她是一位中间派民主党人。但是，天哪，当真正重要的时候，她着眼于历史和子孙后代。”

;

;为了完成范斯坦女士的任期，加利福尼亚州州长加文·纽森 (Gavin Newsom) 迅速任命了前劳工党员拉方扎·巴特勒 (Laphonza Butler)。领导者，曾任;EMILY;'s List的主席，该名单致力于选举支持堕胎权的女性民主党人；她成为第一位公开的女同性恋参议员。 44 岁的巴特勒女士是选举办公室的新人，她尚未决定是否在明年选举时竞选该席位。三名令人敬畏的众议院议员将在三月份决出胜负的民主党初选中展开角逐，这场初选本已成本高昂、伤痕累累。

;

;做正确的事

;

;范斯坦女士在参议院呆得太久了。她从威严的存在变成了令人心酸的存在。然而，她留下的教训并不是关于何时放弃工作，而是首先如何正确地完成工作。她于 1992 年首次赢得席位，当时加州仍在选举一些共和党人担任全州公职。她的继任者不太可能分享她的两党本能，但她或他最好研究一下爱国主义，正是这种爱国主义使范斯坦女士成为她所尊敬的机构的独立思想批评者。

;

;发表酷刑报告并没有造成流血事件。正如范斯坦女士所说，它也没有消除以美国人的名义实施酷刑的污点。但正如她所说，它确实“告诉我们的人民和世界，美国足够大，可以承认错误，并且有足够信心从错误中吸取教训”。这在当时是一个重要的信息，现在也是一个令人欣慰的提醒：美国不仅有能力迷失方向，而且在正确的领导人的帮助下，还能再次找到它。 ;■;

;;T;;诺贝尔奖;;医学;，于 10 月 2 日授予生物化学家卡塔琳·卡里科 (Katalin Karikó)，免疫学家德鲁·韦斯曼 (Drew Weissman) 是一个伟大的失败者故事的完美顶峰。卡里科博士不合时宜地坚持尝试将<小>;RNA;引入细胞，这让她的职业生涯遭遇挫折。她坚持不懈，两人开发了一种技术，使 ;免疫系统;以全新的方式应对威胁。当;covid-19大流行;袭来时，他们研发的 m;RNA; 疫苗拯救了数百万人的生命，并让数十亿人重获正常生活。

;
;;
;

;他们的奖品不同寻常。唯一一位在疫苗接种领域获得诺贝尔奖的科学家是马克斯·泰勒 (Max Theiler)，他发现了黄热病病毒的减毒株，该毒株自 20 世纪 30 年代以来一直被用作疫苗。乔纳斯·索尔克和阿尔伯特·萨宾都没有因开发脊髓灰质炎疫苗而获得奖励。天花的消灭也没有得到庆祝。

;

;鉴于阿尔弗雷德·诺贝尔的遗嘱要求将奖项授予那些为人类带来最大利益的人，这种糟糕的记录是不值得的。不过，尽管他们可能没有去斯德哥尔摩、没有漂亮的脂肪支票和描绘炸药企业家的 175 克金牌，但疫苗科学家们可以考虑更好的事情。正如圣保罗大教堂里克里斯托弗·雷恩 (Christopher Wren) 的铭文所言：;Si纪念碑需要，谨慎;（如果您寻找他的纪念碑，请环顾四周）。疫苗制造商的工作在数亿人的生命中得到纪念。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;世界卫生组织 (;WHO;) 表示疫苗比任何其他医学发明都挽救了更多的人免于死亡。这是一个很难反驳的主张。疫苗可以廉价、可靠且大量地保护人们免受疾病侵害。他们这样做的能力还在不断增强。 2021 年，;世界卫生组织;批准了第一种抗疟疾疫苗；本周，它批准了第二项。

;

;疫苗不仅非常有用，而且非常有用。他们在关怀和沟通方面也体现了美丽的人性。有时人们会说，疫苗不会欺骗免疫系统。他们教育和训练它。作为良好公共卫生的资源，它们允许医生向患者的细胞低声发出警告。在缺乏信任的时代，政府政策与个人免疫系统之间的这种亲密关系很容易被误解为威胁。但疫苗不是阴谋或控制工具：它们是分子的慈爱。

;

;进一步尊重这套非凡技术的最佳方式是更多更好地使用它。 Gavi 是一个公私全球卫生合作伙伴关系，本世纪已向贫困和中等收入国家的儿童提供了超过 10 亿剂各种疫苗；它相信这已经避免了超过 1700 万人死亡。即便如此，仍有数百万儿童根本没有接种疫苗。

;

;人们常说，诺贝尔的遗赠是对他的炸药造成的破坏的赎罪。他的著作没有提供任何证据证明这一点，但他们所造成的损害规模之大——据估计，20 世纪战争中军事使用爆炸物已夺去了 1 亿至 1.5 亿人的生命——如此之大，以至于这个想法似乎应该是真的。疫苗接种是人类为数不多的能够完成这项任务的福利之一。就好像世界能够逆转 20 世纪一场可怕的战争，每年拯救数百万人的生命。 ;如果需要赎罪，请谨慎。 ;;■;

;;T;;巴斯克地区总统伊尼戈·乌尔库鲁 (Iñigo Urkullu) 说得最好。当佩德罗·桑切斯试图重新担任西班牙首相时，乌尔库鲁表示，他将需要“始终获得所有政党的所有选票”。

;
;;
;

;7 月的选举没有让任何政党联盟获得多数席位。 9 月 29 日，中右翼人民党领导人阿尔贝托·努涅斯·费霍 (Alberto Núñez Feijóo) 在议会投票中未能当选总理。这使得桑切斯先生收到了国王的请求，要求他尝试建立自己的多数席位。但桑切斯先生的社会党人和左翼盟友苏马尔甚至比费乔先生更远离多数派。他们需要五个希望从西班牙独立的地区政党的支持。

;
;;

;其中包括 2017 年支持非法独立公投的两个加泰罗尼亚政党。该活动的一些组织者被判入狱，并已被桑切斯先生赦免。但现在他正在谈判一项大赦，这将消除大约一千人的刑事指控，其中最著名的是该地区前总统卡莱斯·普伊格德蒙特(Carles Puigdemont)，他现在是比利时的逃亡者。他将大赦作为获得他的政党 Junts per Catalunya（“共同支持加泰罗尼亚”）的先决条件。

;

;大赦的反对者表示，大赦将严重损害法治，将人们关起来对于普通犯罪，却对政治犯罪放任不管。舆论53%反对，37%赞成。尽管桑切斯先生在国王要求他寻求执政多数席位之前对特赦谈判保持沉默，但他谈到了一个机会“翻开加泰罗尼亚的新一页”。

;

;这将是一件了不起的事情。但加泰罗尼亚的两个主要分离主义政党均表示，他们一如既往地致力于独立。 Junts 和另一党 Esquerra Republica（“共和党左翼”，或 ;ERC;）是领导民族主义事业的激烈竞争对手。他们共同抬高了桑切斯先生的要价。来自;ERC;的地区主席佩雷·阿拉贡内斯(Pere Aragonès)直接反驳了“翻开新页”的说法，称大赦本身并不能解决任何问题。 ;ERC; 和 Junts 通过地区立法机构推动了一项声明，呼吁桑切斯先生“致力于为举行[另一次]公投创造条件”。

;

;通过所有虽然是狡猾的说法，但桑切斯先生显然希望继续管理西班牙，而他需要支持的政党却热衷于重新分裂西班牙。社会党回击分离主义者，称他们的声明毫无帮助，任何协议都必须尊重宪法（保障西班牙领土完整）。

;
;

;宪法法院无论如何都可以否决一项交易。大赦会激怒许​​多西班牙人。桑切斯先生仍然需要向巴斯克和加利西亚民族主义者送去乞讨碗，以便通过法律。但他可能更愿意举行另一次选举来打破僵局。 ;■;

;;;;在被判纵火罪;后，达米安·本德尔 (Damien Bendall) 应该被送进监狱。但为他撰写判前报告的缓刑官没有考虑警方的证据，表明本德尔先生是一名对年轻女孩构成威胁的暴力罪犯。他被判处缓刑，并被允许与怀孕的女友住在一起。几个月后，即 2021 年 9 月，他谋杀了她和三个孩子，其中一个孩子被他强奸了。

;
;;
;

;后来的审查显示，缓刑官员缺乏经验，报告他的作品“非常贫穷”。他确定本德尔先生对伴侣和儿童来说是“低风险”，对公众来说是“中风险”；事实上，他在这两个类别中都应该被归类为“高风险”。在本德尔先生缓刑期间担任管理工作的同事也缺乏经验，他是在六个月前才被招募的。

;

;这个案例异常糟糕，但它说明了该行业普遍存在的问题。缓刑服务处，负责监督在监狱外服刑的罪犯以及一些最近被释放的罪犯。在有关该部门的最新年度报告中，前缓刑首席督察贾斯汀·拉塞尔（Justin Russell）（他于 9 月辞职）描绘了一幅令人不安的画面，说明刑事司法系统的这一关键部分在很大程度上未能履行其职责。 /p>;

;
;
;
;
;
;

;拉塞尔先生最关心的是公共保护。在保障公众安全方面，检查人员认为三分之二的个案处理不够充分。对于那些被归类为“中等风险”的罪犯来说，这一比例甚至更高（大多数缓刑期间的谋杀案都是该营地的人犯下的）。

;
;;

;意味着繁重的工作负载他说，工作人员在每个案件上花费的时间太少。在家工作没有帮助。高级员工缺乏时间审查年轻同事的工作，或指导和支持他们；结果是“错误被遗漏”。其中包括一些令人震惊的基本内容。缓刑官员会定期评估罪犯构成的风险，无论是为了判刑前的报告还是为了确定监狱外的监督程度。拉塞尔先生发现，警察对家庭暴力问题进行调查的比例还不到应有调查的一半；只有 55% 的案件需要对儿童服务进行保障性询问（见图表）。

;

;公共安全并不是缓刑服务摇摇欲坠的唯一受害者。研究表明，由高技能人员对已定罪的罪犯进行个人监督可以大大降低再犯罪率。但劳累过度的缓刑官员并没有与被定罪的罪犯面对面交流，并为他们提供更好的生活所需的支持，而是经常通过电话进行询问。青少年犯罪服务的表现要好得多（大多数被评为“良好”或“优秀”），部分原因是他们的工作人员的案件量要少得多。

;

;出了什么问题？部分答案在于该服务在 2014 年进行了部分私有化，当时该服务被一分为二：一个全国性的公共服务机构，负责处理最严重的罪犯，而社区康复公司 (;crc;s) 则负责处理最严重的犯罪分子。给予经济激励以减少其他犯罪分子的再犯罪。情况如此糟糕，以至于 2021 年决定被推翻。

;

;然而，到那时，许多高级员工已经离开，很大程度上是因为 ;crc; 试图通过摆脱更昂贵的工人。 （因为 ;crc; 没有公布员工人数，直到该服务重新国有化时，这一点才变得明显，当时老板们意识到他们缺少数千名警官。） 缓刑服务部门现在正在努力招募人员，但是米德尔塞克斯大学犯罪学和社会学教授、前缓刑官员安东尼·古德曼 (Anthony Goodman) 表示，“技能的磨合需要时间”。 “你不能只给某人一份清单并说，‘这就是你需要做的’。”

;
;
;
;
;;
;
;

;缓刑服务局的失败也源于长期的变化。缓刑官曾经由地方法院任命；近几十年来，对任命和政策的控制逐渐从司法部门转移到设在威斯敏斯特的国家服务部门。斯旺西大学犯罪学教授、前缓刑监督官彼得·雷诺表示，集中化也会影响法院对罪犯的判决方式，尤其是社区判刑，社区判刑的再犯罪率低于监禁，但使用率太低。 “当缓刑在当地进行并涉及当地判刑者时，法院对社区判决有更多的了解，并对社区判决更有信心。”

;

;拉塞尔先生在报告中表示，现在是时候进行独立审查以了解情况了。缓刑是否应该“回归到更地方化的治理形式”。回归更加本地化的控制的理由看起来很引人注目。 ;■;

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 14:27:02 +0800 After a brutal campaign, Poland gets ready to vote | Europehttps://www.economist.com/europe/2023/10/05/after-a-brutal-campaign-poland-gets-ready-to-vote ;
;
;

;;E;;LBLAG, A GRITTY; port where the air stings from factory soot, is not exactly full of latte-sipping cosmopolitans. In Poland's bitterly divided politics, urban voters mostly back liberals; in Elblag in 2019 the ruling hard-right Law and Justice (;P;i;S;) party came first. Yet when Donald Tusk, the centrist running to unseat ;P;i;S;, arrived for a rally on September 28th, the hall was jammed. For years, he cried, ;P;i;S; had packed Poland's courts and bickered with the ;EU;. Mr Tusk (pictured), who served as prime minister from 2007-14 and then as president of the European Council, promised to end all that: “Europe is freedom, the rule of law, the fight against corruption.” ;P;i;S ;was trying to brainwash Poles, he said, just as the communists and Nazis had.

;
;;
;

;If Mr Tusk's language was harsh, the rhetoric at a ;P;i;S ;gathering outside Warsaw a day earlier was acid. Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the party's leader, claimed that in a war with Russia Mr Tusk would surrender half of Poland's territory. The group Mr Tusk heads, Civic Coalition (;KO;), would help the ;EU ;ship in illegal migrants. Mr Tusk wants to instil “German order” in Poland, Mr Kaczynski said, just like the Nazis. The speech was only slightly less rabid than one in August when he called Mr Tusk “pure evil” and said the opposition should be “morally exterminated”.

;

;Polish politics has always been rough, but the campaign for this year's general election, scheduled for October 15th, is setting records for vitriol. The government is scared: after years of scandals, it has a good chance of losing power. The opposition, for its part, fears that with one more term ;PiS ;could so cement its hold over the state that democracy would become a sham, as it has in Hungary under Viktor Orban. Both sides are piling on the stakes.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The question is whether undecided voters are listening. Polls show a tight race. ;P;i;S;'s hold on its mostly older voters is solid, but may be near its peak. Younger Poles tend to back the opposition, but they also tend not to vote. Many find none of the parties appealing. Mr Tusk is 66, Mr Kaczynski 74; they have been in the political arena for decades. This contest will probably be the final one between these duelling icons of Polish populism and liberalism. But it may be decided by a new generation that cares for neither of them.

;

;;P;i;S ;will almost certainly come first. But polls give it perhaps 37%, well below the 44% it won in 2019 and far short of a majority. When ;P;i;S ;came to power in 2015 it introduced a hugely popular child-benefit scheme and lowered the retirement age, but its second term has been plagued by misfires. In 2020 an animal-welfare bill (Mr Kaczynski's pet project) was binned after farmers revolted. A court ruling later that year banned abortion except in cases of rape, incest or to protect the health of the mother, leading to months of protests (the “Women's Strike”) and alienating some of ;P;i;S;'s own female voters. Earlier this year ;P;i;S ;had to water down a bill to investigate Russian influence on public figures that was clearly aimed at producing dirt on the opposition. To pacify angry farmers the government blocked imports of Ukrainian grain, sparking a diplomatic crisis.

;

;Finally, in September, a bribery scandal erupted in the foreign ministry. Hundreds of thousands of visas may have been improperly issued to Asians and Africans. (In one case a group of Indians pretended to shoot a Bollywood movie in Poland, then flew on to Mexico, where they tried to cross into America.) The scandal hurts ;P;i;S ;in one of its core issues: immigration.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;Many voters give ;P;i;S ;credit for Poland's prosperity. ;GDP; grew 3.2% per year in the decade to 2021, and the government has invested in poor regions, especially in the east, where ;P;i;S ;is strongest. Slow roads and trains have been replaced with fast ones. The government has reopened hundreds of police stations closed when Mr Tusk was in power. Outside the eastern city of Lublin, Robert, an ;IT ;worker, says he wishes ;P;i;S ;“stole less”, but prefers it to the opposition because it spreads the money around. Andrzej Zybertowicz, a sociologist who advises Poland's president, Andrzej Duda, thinks even voters who dislike ;P;i;S ;may fear that a new team would disrupt their benefits. Rural voters viscerally distrust Mr Tusk, recalling his raising of the retirement age in 2012. He is seen to have abandoned Poland for glitzy Brussels. But ;KO; has done little to change their minds, tailoring its message to urban voters.

;

;;P;i;S;'s control of the state apparatus is the root of its power. Orlen, a state company that owns most of the country's petrol stations, has kept prices low before the election—so low that many pumps have run out of fuel. The government will reward counties for high election turnout with money for fire stations, but only in rural areas (which tend to vote for ;P;i;S;). Parliament has refused to update electoral districts to reflect population changes, so liberal cities have too few ;MP;s. The Election Observatory, a watchdog, estimates that Warsaw should have 34 seats rather than its current 20. Meanwhile, the government will stage referendums alongside the election on questions such as whether to tear down Poland's border fence, falsely implying that the opposition supports this.

;

;Yet trying to capture the state has hurt ;P;i;S;, too. Its efforts to give the government control of the judiciary have been ruled illegal by the European Court of Justice. The ;EU ;is withholding €35bn ($37bn) in covid-recovery funds until more of the changes are rolled back. (Mr Tusk notes that this means Polish taxpayers are in effect funding German infrastructure.) The government has made moves to comply, but these are “just for show”, says Ewa Wrzosek, a prosecutor and rule-of-law activist. Meanwhile ;P;i;S;'s power-grabs have touched off a rule-of-law movement that has mobilised support for liberal goals. The women's movement catalysed by ;P;i;S;'s abortion ban plays a similar role. “There's been a huge political backlash on women's rights,” says Monika Chabior, deputy mayor of the city of Gdansk, who got her start as an organiser during the Women's Strike.

;

;Young people are often concerned with issues that do not line up with nationalism or liberalism. Many are frustrated by sky-high housing prices. Others worry about depression and mental health. On the left they gravitate to the Lewica (The Left) party. On the right they may embrace Confederation, a boozy far-right libertarian group that bashes ;P;i;S;'s spending on welfare (and on Ukrainian refugees). Both were recently polling at about 10%, but the gender split is huge: Confederation draws three times more men than women. In the past few weeks it has been hurt by racism scandals and poor debate performances. Some of its voters may shift to Third Way, an alliance of two centrist parties, one headed by a former journalist and reality-;TV; host.

;
;

;No coalition option looks secure. Confederation intermittently vows not to govern with ;P;i;S;, and would be a fickle partner anyway. ;KO;, Lewica and Third Way may together scrape a majority. But President Duda, who comes from ;P;i;S;, could frustrate their efforts to govern—as could courts controlled by ;P;i;S ;appointees. That might mean new elections soon. But the opposition's spirits are high. On October 1st it drew an estimated 600,000-800,000 people to a march in Warsaw. State television, controlled by ;P;i;S;, did not cover it live. ;■;

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 13:57:03 +0800 What should Ireland’s government do with a huge budget surplus? | Europehttps://www.economist.com/europe/2023/10/05/what-should-irelands-government-do-with-a-huge-budget-surplus ;
;
;

;;B;;loated by the; offshore profits of global corporations, the Irish economy has long been prone to manic mood swings. In 2016 Paul Krugman, an economist and commentator, coined the phrase “leprechaun economics” to describe a surge of 26% in Ireland's ;GDP ;that was later found to have been caused largely by accounting changes at Apple, one of several American tech and pharma giants that book much of their global profits in Ireland.

;
;;
;

;In Irish folklore, leprechauns were grumpy sprites who hoarded pots of gold at the ends of rainbows. Some wily mortal would invariably trick the little chap out of his stash. Boosted by corporate tax from overseas companies, the Irish government faces a budget surplus of €10bn ($10.5bn, or 3.5% of ;GNI;) this year and maybe €16bn the next. Yet this bonanza puts Ireland's finance minister, Michael McGrath, poised to unveil his annual budget, in a quandary.

;

;With ;GNP ;up by 11% in this year's second quarter and unemployment at only 4%, the economy is churning at full capacity. Any splurge of spending or tax cuts would probably drive up inflation, already running at 6.3%—far above the euro-zone target of 2%. Even so, the two centre-right parties that dominate the ruling coalition have been hinting at cuts in income tax. Fine Gael (led by the prime minister, Leo Varadkar) and Fianna Fail (led by a former prime minister, Michael Martin) may be eyeing elections, which are due within two years. A sovereign-wealth fund for a rainy day, to cover future pension and welfare liabilities, is also being considered.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Yet opinion polls suggest that the Irish people want the windfall to be spent on longer-term investment, particularly infrastructure, and most of all on housing. The Celtic Tiger's housing bubble of the 2000s produced a big surplus of new homes before it burst in 2008, leaving the Irish on the hook for an $89bn international bail-out loan. Lean years followed. Soaring rents and a shortage of properties now leave many young people with no affordable place to live; homelessness is rising. ;IBEC;, a lobby group for businesses in Ireland, says that lack of housing for workers is harming economic growth.

;

;So far Ireland's government, understandably cautious, has resisted calls for a big state-led programme of house-building. Ireland has had a patchy record in this respect. A new 380-bed children's hospital, originally priced at €650m, is now projected to cost €2.2bn. An underground railway project for Dublin, mooted decades ago, has so far seen €300m spent on planning and consultants but has yet to break ground. Its estimated cost has soared from €3.5bn 20 years ago to as high as €12bn.

;

;Meanwhile, the money that flows in so easily from the likes of Apple, Google, Meta and Pfizer can all too easily flow out again. The ;EU ;and America dislike Ireland's low corporate tax rate of 12.5%. The Irish government knows there could be a crock of something at the end of the rainbow, but fears it may not be gold. ;■;

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 13:57:03 +0800 Kevin McCarthy’s sacking deepens the chaos in American government | United Stateshttps://www.economist.com/united-states/2023/10/04/kevin-mccarthys-sacking-deepens-the-chaos-in-american-government ;
;
;

;;K;;evin McCarthy's; stint as speaker of America's House of Representatives ended the way it had begun: in utterly ;humiliating; fashion. On October 3rd members of the lower chamber of Congress disposed of their leader for the first time in American history.尽管获得了 221 名众议院共和党人中 210 名的支持，;八名强硬派;与 208 名民主党人联手解雇了麦卡锡先生。 Shortly thereafter the former speaker announced that he would not try to regain the title. The coming weeks are likely to be chaotic, and the results of this chapter of congressional dysfunction will reverberate far beyond Capitol Hill.

;
;;
;

;An embarrassing ejection appeared to be on the cards as soon as Mr McCarthy won the speaker's gavel in January. As part of a deal with recalcitrant Republicans after 15 rounds of voting, Mr McCarthy agreed to allow a single congressman, at any time, for any reason, to call a vote for his removal as speaker. Matt Gaetz, an elaborately coiffed representative from Florida, had threatened to use the so-called motion to vacate for some time. Mr McCarthy's recent dealmaking with Democrats to avoid a government shutdown pushed Mr Gaetz over the edge.

;

;“You all know Matt Gaetz. You know it was personal,” Mr McCarthy said at a press conference after being ousted. Mr Gaetz denies that personal pique drove his fight against the former speaker, but the Florida Republican has faced a long-running House Ethics Committee inquiry into alleged sexual misconduct and misuse of funds. No doubt he was not thrilled that Mr McCarthy failed to stop the investigation. Yet the rebel leader probably had a mix of motives for making his move now.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;“He's very, very sharp, very calculated, and very intelligent: a political pro,” says Christian Ziegler, chairman of the Florida Republican Party. “This isn't someone that's just doing something uncalculated off the cuff and in the heat of the moment. Everything is very meticulously planned when Matt Gaetz takes action.” Mr Gaetz enjoys the spotlight, and he also raised funds during this fight, which surely made him enemies on Capitol Hill. That is less important for someone who could be eyeing the governor's mansion in Florida.

;

;For all his faults, Mr McCarthy overcame thin margins during his time in office. In May he managed to persuade the House to raise the debt ceiling, to avoid a damaging default.然后，9 月 30 日，他在最后一刻推动了两党达成协议，推迟代价高昂的政府关门。 The next speaker may find the job harder still, even without the same baggage that some in the unruly Republican Party felt that Mr McCarthy carried.

;

;The immediate task will be funding the government. The deal to avert a shutdown keeps the government going with a “continuing resolution” (;CR;) only until November 17th. A Republican strategist, Liam Donovan, reckons Mr Gaetz might be satisfied with Mr McCarthy gone, but other hardliners will not easily accept a long-term funding solution simply because a fresh face is running the House. Government will have to be funded “in a way that is even more anathema to these Republicans than the ;CR;,” Mr Donovan says. Mr McCarthy's replacement could soon be overseeing a shutdown. Averting a closure could potentially cost the new speaker his job.

;

;Aid for Ukraine, which was not included in the government-funding deal in order to placate hardliners, is the greatest concern for those beyond America's borders.在宣布离职的新闻发布会上，麦卡锡将弗拉基米尔·普京与阿道夫·希特勒进行了比较，并表示当今的世界让他想起了 1930 年代。 He reiterated his support for Ukraine and rightly criticised President Joe Biden for his past hesitance on arming the country.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;But some House Republicans have begun to ;oppose further funding;. Mr McCarthy suggested a quid pro quo, in which aid for the government in Kyiv could be approved if Democrats help pass policies to shore up America's porous border. ;Supporters of Ukraine; in Congress, who constitute a clear majority in both chambers, are pushing for a vote that would guarantee funding for the war-torn country up until the 2024 American presidential election. Threading this legislative needle could be even more difficult than avoiding a government shutdown.

;

;To whom that task will fall is not obvious. Patrick McHenry, a North Carolina Republican hand-picked by Mr McCarthy, will serve as acting speaker and will merely oversee the election of Mr McCarthy's replacement. Republicans are planning for a candidate forum on October 10th and a vote the following day. But the real question is who among the Republicans has the mental fitness to do the job—and is mad enough to seek it.

;

;No one expects a consensus figure to emerge as quickly as, for example, Paul Ryan did when he replaced John Boehner as speaker in 2015. Steve Scalise, the second-ranked Republican in the House, has thrown his hat in the ring. So has Jim Jordan, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, who has credibility with the right as a former Freedom Caucus head who managed to work productively with McCarthy allies. Kevin Hern seems to want the job, too: he leads the Republican Study Committee, which counts a majority of the House party as members. Yet uncertainty could pave the way for a dark horse. (Marjorie Taylor Greene, a prominent member of the Republican berserker caucus, tweeted that the only candidate she was supporting for speaker was Donald Trump.)

;

;The chaos and intrigue will be as entertaining as any episode of “The West Wing”, a Washington-focused television drama.对于希望政府保持开放的美国人，或者依靠美国的力量和慷慨来维持生存斗争的乌克兰人来说，这并不能带来什么安慰。 ;■;

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 04:57:02 +0800 Sharon Todd on turning Britain into a science superpower | By Invitationhttps://www.economist.com/by-invitation/2023/10/04/sharon-todd-on-turning-britain-into-a-science-superpower ;
;
;

;;R;;ISHI SUNAK'S ;laudable ambition to turn Britain into a science superpower has moved innovation up the political agenda.这是一个值得欢迎的进展，反对党的言论也反映了这一点。

;

;Ambitious as the prime minister may sound, however, words are not enough.在应对新挑战的经济转型竞赛中，英国已经远远落后于国际竞争对手。如果它想利用其全球公认的科学研究优势，就必须立即采取行动，否则将面临经济永久性衰退的风险。

;

;Research by ;LEK; Consulting, commissioned by the Society of Chemical Industry (;SCI;), shows that without a detailed, focused industrial strategy for life sciences and clean tech, Britain will lose out on £230bn ($280bn) of gross value added (a measure of the value of goods and services produced) and 240,000 jobs by 2030 in those two sectors alone.作为研究一部分接受采访的所有公司都指出英国的竞争力正在下降。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;SCI;, a charity that has connected industry, academia and government since 1881, has developed a Manifesto for an Industrial Science & Innovation Strategy.这为科学的整个生命周期提供了一个政策框架，从一个想法的起源到确保多年后的任何大规模生产都在英国进行。 If the government adopts this strategy in full soon, Britain might still have a chance of becoming a science superpower.

;

;The proposals range across eight policy areas.其中三个涵盖了以科学为基础的企业的整个生命周期。其他措施则涉及在特定时刻进行干预，即当一项创新因缺乏国内支持而面临停止或被转移到海外的风险时。

;

;The first overarching policy area is the need for an Innovation & Science Growth Council, with a direct line to the prime minister. Membership would include bosses of large science-based businesses, startup founders and academics.

;

;This council would replace many of the roughly 70 scientific advisory bodies across government, which have caused confusion and crowd out the voice of business. Industrial experts would advise ministers on the most effective ways of commercialising Britain's best research and development (;R&D;). Work would include developing dedicated, government-supported science enterprise zones; and adopting the recommendations of Lord Hill's ;UK ;Listings Review, which looked into how Britain can attract more innovative firms and improve access to growth finance. Its recommendations include changes to listing rules and a review of statutory objectives of the Financial Conduct Authority (;FCA;), a regulator. The changes would add; a duty for the ;FCA; to consider Britain's attractiveness to investors when crafting rules.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The second broad policy area looks at simplifying ;R&D; for scientific companies of all sizes with a single, more investor-friendly tax-relief system. We also call for annual public; R&D; spending to be set at a minimum of 0.6% of ;GDP;, the ;OECD; average. Based on Britain's current spending, just 0.46% of ;GDP; (ranking it 27th out of the ;OECD;'s 38 members), this would amount to around £3bn per year of additional money.

;

;The third key area is reform of the visa system.我们的成员担心，缺乏灵活性和过多的官僚主义正在鼓励科学家前往其他地方。我们建议技术工人签证的有效期应长达十年，而不是目前的最长五年，科学家应该能够在这十年内更自由地流动，这样他们就可以在其他国家学习技能，然后在英国应用。

;

;The use of technology transfer offices (;TTO;s) also needs reviewing. ;TTO;s are typically created within universities to manage their intellectual-property assets and how they are transferred to industry.他们与大学衍生公司合作，通过早期投资（通常以换取大量股权）来帮助加速增长。 ;TTO;s can be vital for startups. However, some ;TTO;s take too much equity, leaving businesses they invest in less attractive to other investors later on. Our proposals include a standard agreement structure for all ;TTO;s, limiting their equity stake to 20%.

;

;Funding of startups requires patient capital as science businesses take longer to generate returns than firms in most other sectors;. ;Many of our members, however, worry that British rules on early-stage capital and allowances are unnecessarily complicated.此外，对公司可以结转的税收损失的限制阻碍了私募股权和风险资本的投资。 These rules should be simplified and loosened so investors are encouraged to support companies until they become profitable.

;

;Another area ripe for reform is pension funds.我们欢迎政界人士最近对此的关注，尤其是英国财政大臣杰里米·亨特 (Jeremy Hunt) 7 月推出的所谓“豪宅改革”，旨在增加对高增长企业的投资并提高储户的回报。然而，我们注意到，英国养老金资金规模通常较小，这意味着基金经理往往倾向于规避风险的策略。我们的建议包括汇集养老金资产和放宽阻止资金投资初创企业和规模化企业（进一步沿着增长轨道前进的企业）的规则。

;

;AstraZeneca's decision in 2021 to build a $400m factory in Ireland rather than Britain because of our “discouraging” tax system was a wake-up call.这标志着英国最重要的以科学为基础的跨国公司不再认为其祖国是一个有吸引力的投资地。我们提出了税收优惠措施，以鼓励大型生产设施的建设。其资格将取决于创造的就业机会、开发技术已花费的金额以及更广泛的经济效益。

;

;Similarly, Britain could use net-zero tax credits to encourage large investments that help the country meet its greenhouse-gas-reduction targets.英国还需要一个针对资本投资超级扣除的更严格的后继方案，重点关注环保资产。加计扣除为资本支出提供130%的资本免税额扣除。 Its cancellation in March stoked corporate concerns about Britain's waning attractiveness.

;

;This is not an exhaustive list of the ;SCI ;manifesto's recommendations.用政治术语来说，我们的建议提供了一种现成的工业战略。我们敦促各种政治色彩的政党立即采用它们，以免对我们的经济来说为时已晚。 ;■;

;

;;T;;he origins; of covid-19 remain unknown.大多数科学家认为，病毒是在武汉的一个肉类市场从野生动物传染给人类的。但它也有可能是从同一城市的病毒学研究实验室逃脱的。

;Now a similar argument has broken out around bitcoin, the first and most used cryptocurrency.比特币的公认起源是它是由化名程序员中本聪发明的，他于 2008 年发表了一篇描述比特币的论文，后来就从人们的视线中消失了。

;

;But a theory circulating online holds that bitcoin was dreamed up by the National Security Agency (;NSA;), an American spy agency that also does cutting-edge cryptography research. “I think it was a shuttered internal ;R;&;D; project which one researcher thought was too good to lay fallow on the shelf and chose to secretly release,” tweeted Nic Carter, a prominent bitcoin fan. Mr Carter and his fellow travellers think they have a smoking gun: a paper written in 1996 by ;NSA; employees entitled “How to make a mint: the cryptography of anonymous electronic cash”. And the paper cites work by a researcher named “Tatsuaki Okamoto”.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;But the paper is more smoke than gun.它只是对可能用于数字现金的加密思想的调查。与比特币不同的是，比特币的一大创新在于其去中心化设计，而本文中的计划依赖于监督机构。它讨论了电子现金给税收和执法带来的风险。 “Thus the idea that the ;NSA; would develop a decentralised, trustless cryptocurrency as a 'monetary bioweapon' that would impair their own government's functions” is implausible,” writes David Rosenthal, a cryptocurrency sceptic, on his blog.

;

;Just another conspiracy theory, then?几乎可以确定。但类似的事情以前也发生过。 In 1997 it emerged that Clifford Cocks, a mathematician at ;GCHQ;, Britain's ;NSA; equivalent, had secretly invented a vital cryptographic technology that underlies both bitcoin and the internet in general, several years before the trio of American researchers who had been given credit.

;

;A better parallel between bitcoin and covid-19 may be that, like the virus, the cryptocurrency has proved hard to kill off.尽管去年发生了严重的崩盘，比特币的价值仍然在 27,500 美元左右。 ;■;
